State Key Laboratory of Photocatalysis on Energy and Environment College of Chemistry Fuzhou University Fuzhou Fujian 350116 China The size-selected copper single-cluster catalysts(SCCs) play a crucial role in catalyzing of CO2 hydrogenation. However, nature of size effect and hydrogenation mechanism is still unclear. Here, Density functional theory(DFT) calculations were performed to investigate activation and reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over copper single-clusters catalyst anchored on α-Al2O3(0001). Our results show that Cun(n = 1–9)/Al2O3 catalysts significantly promote activation of CO2 in a bent configuration due to the synergistic interaction associated with Cun-Al2O3(0001) interfacial site. Bader charge analysis suggested electron transfer occurring from Cun-Al2O3(0001) interface to CO2, leading to negatively charged CO2. We find descriptors of deviation of CO2 bonds length and bonds angle, d -band center of Cun(n = 1–9) cluster that can well descript for determining activation degree of CO2. Especially, the Cu5/α-Al2O3(0001) has the best activity for CO2 hydrogenation among them. Furthermore, reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation at Cu5/Al2O3 interface have been explored. Methanol synthesis takes formate route and direct CO bond cleavage route competitive with rate-dominant step of HCOO* and HO* hydrogenation, respectively. While CO-hydrogenation produced by RWGS route is not feasible because of high activation barrier of formed CO intermediate(1.95 eV). This study will provide insight into designing and application of ultrahigh-performance Cu-based single-cluster catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. Introduction With the increasing of CO2 emission caused by burning of fossil fuels, environment change and energy crisis worldwide have become gradually serious facing us today [1,2]. Recently, strategies to capture and recycling utilize of CO2 into chemicals and fuels have received enormous attention [3–8]. CO2 reduction to formic acid [9,10], methane [11,12] and methanol [13,14] are important and attractive solution for CO2 conversion. Among them, the hydrogenation of CO2 into methanol is a crucial sustainable technology which is even considered as a great substitute fuel for gasoline and key chemical intermediates for industrial processes [15–19]. However, exploring highly active catalysts with efficient transformation of CO2 into methanol is still a major challenge because of the difficulties with the chemical inertness of CO2 [20–22]. Since 1960s, the chemical processes of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol have been performed by Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts at high pressures (50 − 100 atm) and temperatures (450 − 600 ℃) [23–25]. Recently, developing effective low-pressure catalysts to modification and improvement of the activity performance for methanol synthesis from CO2 has become the focus of the interest [26–28]. Rui et al. [29] reported that noble metal Pd nanoparticles dispersed on In2O3 was beneficial for dissociation of hydrogen and hydrogenation of CO2, providing a super-performance of high CO2 conversion (>20 %) and methanol selectivity (>70 %). Zeng et al. [30] presented neighboring Pt monomers dispersed on MoS2 greatly improved the catalytic activity of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol without the formation of formic acid due to the synergy between neighboring Pt monomers. Moreover, extensive researches have been focused on the non-noble Cu-based catalysts. Meunier et al. [31] reported that Cu/ZrO2 as a potential catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Copper surface play a crucial role which can not only effectively activate H2, but also further bears main reaction intermediates. Graciani et al. [25] demonstrated Cu/CeO2 catalysts is highly efficient for CO2 reduction to methanol, which attributed catalytic activity to the synergistic interaction at the copper-ceria interface. Chen et al. [32] obtained metallic (Cu/ZnO/Al2O3) catalysts by a facile alcohol solvent assisted method. The catalyst exhibit a much higher methanol yield than other catalysts synthesized by conventional method. Mao et al. [33] prepared a Cu-ZnO/Cu@Si catalyst which was significantly promoted CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, due to the synergistic effects between Cu-O-Si structure and Cu-ZnO interface. Despite enormous studies and development, the active site and the reaction mechanism in catalytic process are still unclear. The activity and selectivity of catalyst for CO2 conversion to methanol are still less than satisfactory. Recently, single-atom catalysts (SAC) and single-cluster catalysts (SCC), as forefronts of heterogeneous catalysts, have attracted increasing attention due to their unique physical and chemical properties and excellent catalytic efficiency [34–36]. A number of experimental and theoretical studies have proved that small-sized metal cluster catalysts appear to exhibit excellent catalytic activity for complex reactions, which are significantly different from those of the conventional bulk metal surface and supported nanoparticle catalyst [37–40]. What's more, the catalytic performances are also closely related to the size of supported single-cluster [41]. Fu et al. [42] introduced different size of Pt nanoparticles and Pt single atoms onto CeO2 via a laser ablation method, which revealed that synergistic effect of nano-single-atom catalyst greatly improved catalytic activity. The Pt10 was regarded as the major active center while Pt1 decreased the energy barrier for CO oxidation by lattice oxygen and leaded to an overall performance improvement. Liu et al. [43] reported that Cu cluster on amorphous Al2O3 catalysts exhibit unexpected high CO2 conversion and selectivity to CH3OH at low pressure. However, determined active site of catalyst and understanding the promotion of different size effect remain controversial, and the reaction mechanism in the catalytic process is still unclear. Herein, in this paper, we systematically investigate a series of Cun(n = 1 − 9) clusters supported on α-Al2O3(0001) surface as model catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol and focus on the size effect on CO2 activation and reaction mechanism based on the van der Waals-corrected density functional theory (DFT-D3) calculations. Our result provide an understanding for the design and development of high-efficiency Cu-based single-cluster catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. Computational details All the spin-polarized DFT calculations were performed by the Vienna ab-initio Simulation Package [44,45]. The projector-augmented plane wave (PAW) [46] was set to describe electron-ion interactions, and the generalized gradient approximation(GGA) with the Perdew-Burke- Ernzerhof(PBE) exchange-correlation functional was employed [47]. A 450 eV plane-wave cutoff energy was used. A 3 × 3 × 1 Γ-centered k-points was used for structural relaxation and electronic property calculations. A vacuum space of 15 Å was set to avoid interactions between the adjacent slabs. The energy convergence was set to 1 × 10−5 eV. The force convergence was set to 0.03 eV/Å. The effects of van der Waals forces were considered by vdw-DF3 method [48]. The dipole correction was included for slab model. The structures of α-Al2O3(0001) surface with Al-terminated was modeled by a nine-layer slab in which the bottom three layers were fixed and the top six layers were relaxed, which is consistent with previous works [49–51]. A (2 × 2) supercell (consisting of 24 Al and 36 O atoms) and a (3 × 3) supercell of α-Al2O3(0001) surface (consisting of 54 Al and 81 O atoms) were adopted for the supported small Cun (n = 1 – 5) and large Cun (n = 6 – 9) clusters, respectively. Because there are many possible structures of the copper clusters anchored on the α-Al2O3(0001) surface, an ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulation using the Nosé algorithm [52] was used to screen possible structures of Cun/α-Al2O3(0001). 10 ps simulation with a time step of 1 fs at temperature of 600 K and 300 eV low cutoff energy was used. Typical structures were further screened from the results of AIMD simulations. Finally further structural optimizations using above accurate settings were used to examine the most stable structure of Cun/Al2O3(0001). This approach was verified in our previous work such as Ann/MoS2 and Au/TiOx/Mo(112) [40,53]. The transition states (TS) were searched by the climbing-image nudged elastic band method with 8 images and further verified by a single imaginary frequency [54,55]. The microkinetic simulations were conducted to investigate the rate-limiting step with the evaluating of degree of rate control (DRC) proposed by Campbell [56,57]. The binding energy per Cu atom(E b) for Cun cluster supported on the α-Al2O3(0001) surface was calculated by following equation, E b = [ E ( α − A l 2 O 3 ) + E ( C u n ) − E ( C u n / α − A l 2 O 3 ) ] / n Where E(Cun/α-Al2O3), E(Cun), and E(α-Al2O3) refer to the total energies of Cun/α-Al2O3(0001) system, Cun cluster in gas phase and pristine α-Al2O3(0001) surface, respectively. For the chemisorption of CO2 molecule on the Cun/α-Al2O3(0001) surface, the adsorption energy (E ads) was defined as, E ads = [ E ( C u n / α − A l 2 O 3 ) + E ( C O 2 ) − E ( C O 2 / C u n / α − A l 2 O 3 ) ] Where E(CO2/Cun/α-Al2O3), E(Cun/α-Al2O3), and E(CO2) denote the total energies of CO2 adsorbed on Cun/α-Al2O3(0001), the pristine Cun/α-Al2O3(0001), and free CO2 molecule in the gas phase, respectively. The activation barrier (E a) of elementary reaction step for the CO2 synthesis to methanol is defined as E a = E ( TS ) − E ( IS ) Where E(TS) and E(IS) refer to the total energies of transition state and initial structure, respectively. The associated reaction energy (E r) of each step is defined as E r = E ( FS ) − E ( IS ) Where E(FS) and E(IS) refer to the total energies of final structure and initial structure, respectively. Results and discussion Structures and stability of Cun/α-Al2O3 (0001) surfaces Before considering the case of deposition of copper clusters, we first discuss the configurations of Cun clusters in gas phase. The structures of Cun clusters with different sizes in gas phase have been studied using DFT calculations combined with the random search algorithm in previous studies [58–60]. Here the structure and the stability of Cun clusters (placed in a 20 × 20 × 20 cubic box) are reexamined at PBE level with plane-wave basis set (Fig. S1 and Table S1). The results show that the ground state structures of Cun clusters (n = 3–6) are all planar with triangle, rhombus, half-hexagon and triangular, respectively. While different from the hexamer, the most stable configuration of Cu7, Cu8 and Cu9 exhibit a three-dimensional structure with symmetry of D5h, C2v and Cs, respectively. The cohesive energy of Cun that is defined as E c = [E(Cun) − n × E(Cu)]/n was calculated to evaluate the stability of cluster. As shown in Table S1, it can be found that the cohesive energy gradually increased from 1.13 to 2.20 eV with the number of the Cu atoms, indicating the Cu-Cu bonds of the Cun clusters become stronger. Moreover, average Cu-Cu bond length also presents an increasing trend from 2.336 to 2.436 Å as number of the Cu atoms varies from 2 to 9. The above results are consistent with those obtained in previous study [59]. Although several studies have explored metal clusters supported on Al2O3, only a few researches focused on different size of Cun clusters anchored on the α-Al2O3 (0001) surface. Different Cun clusters anchored on α-Al2O3 (0001) surface are screened based on the AIMD simulations. The most stable configurations of Cun(n = 1–9)/α-Al2O3 (0001) are provided in Fig. 1 . Some structural parameters and the binding energy per Cu atom (E b) are shown in Table 1 . As shown in Fig. 1, our results show that most of Cu clusters are anchored on the substrate via Cu-O and Cu-Al bonds. Taking the stability of Cun/α-Al2O3 (0001) into consideration, binding energy is applied to evaluate thermodynamically stability of each system. It can be found that all the binding energies of Cun/α-Al2O3 (0001) are positive, indicated that the deposition of copper clusters are exothermic process for all systems due to the presence of strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) (Table 1). For Cu1 (Fig. 1a), a single Cu atom prefers to be adsorbed at the center of three surface O atoms to form a tetrahedron structure with E b = 2.84 eV, which is larger than the Pd atom on α-Al2O3 (0001) surface (1.49 eV) [61]. All bond lengths of Cu-O were 2.085 Å. For Cu2, one Cu atom still favors to bond to three surface O atoms with average Cu-O bond length of 2.114 Å (Fig. 1b). In addition, one Cu-Al bond with a length of 2.494 Å is formed, and the Cu-Cu bond length slightly increases to 2.332 Å. The binding energy of copper dimer is calculated to be 1.70 eV. As shown in Fig. 1c, the Cu3 cluster can be anchored on the Al2O3 (0001) by the formations of Cu-O and Cu-Al bonds. The average Cu-Cu bond length is obvious increased to 2.396 Å. On the contrary, after depositions on the Al2O3 (0001), the original planar configurations of Cun clusters with n = 4 − 6 are destroyed. Now Cu4 is anchored by a tetrahedral structure with five Cu-O bonds (2.116 Å) at the interface (Fig. 1d). The average Cu-Cu bonds distance is 2.445 Å and the binding energy per Cu atom is 1.12 eV. While for Cu5 cluster, it shows a trigonal bipyramid arrangement with four Cu-O and one Cu-Al bond. The average Cu-Cu bond length slightly enlarges to 2.195 Å and the binding energy is 0.97 eV. In the case of Cu6, it places on the surface via the formation of five Cu-O bonds with an average length of 2.038 Å (Fig. 1f). For those Cun clusters with large sizes (namely, n = 7 − 9), although the Cun clusters remain the original 3D stacking structure, depositions on Al2O3 substrate lead to obvious changes of their configurations compared with that in gas phase. For Cu7, six Cu-O bonds with an average bond length of 2.124 Å are observed at interface (Fig. 1g). The Cu8 cluster is supported on Al2O3 substrate by five Cu-O bonds (2.098 Å) and one Cu-Al bond (2.527 Å) (Fig. 1h). For comparison, there are five Cu-O bonds and three Cu-Al bonds at the interface between Cu9 cluster and the substrate (Fig. 1i). The E b values of Cu7, Cu8 and Cu9 clusters are predicted to be 0.88, 0.79 and 0.78 eV, respectively. To investigate the effect of deposition of Cun clusters with different size on the electronic structure, the variations of the Bader charge, d -band center and surface work function of Cun/α-Al2O3 (0001) system were determined as shown in Table 1. The total charges of all Cun clusters supported on the Al2O3(0001) are positive, indicating the electron transfer occurring from copper cluster to the substrate. Moreover, the charge transfer of Cu5/Al2O3(0001) can also be verified by the result of the charge density difference (CDD) as shown in Fig. 2 a. It is can be seen that the lost electrons of Cu5 cluster transfer to the interface near the Al2O3(0001) surface. Interestingly, the value of average d-band center of Cu5/α-Al2O3(0001) is −1.43 eV, which is the highest among Cun(n = 1–9)/α-Al2O3(0001) systems considered in here (−3.01 eV – −1.53 eV). The d -band center of supported Cu5 cluster shifts closer to the Fermi level, result in stronger activation ability to CO2. Therefore, the position of d -band center implies that binding of Cu5 cluster will facilitate the activation of CO2 molecule at the interface, due to the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) between Cu5 cluster and the substrate. Furthermore, the change of surface work function with respect to the pristine Al2O3(0001) surface was calculated to further understand the effect of supported Cun cluster on the activation of CO2 as displayed in Table 1. Work function is decreased with different degrees in all cases due to the transfer of electrons from copper cluster to Al2O3(0001) surface. Notably, the most obvious reduction of work function (−2.02 eV) is predicted for Cu5-supported surface, suggested that the Cu5/Al2O3(0001) has the strongest ability to donate electrons and is most favorable for CO2 activation. CO2 adsorption on the interfacial site of the Cun/α-Al2O3(0001) surfaces The adsorption activiation of CO2 molecules on the Cun(n = 1–9)/α-Al2O3 (0001) surface was further investigated. The most stable configurations of CO2 adsorption on the Cun(n = 1–9)/α-Al2O3(0001) are shown in Fig. 3 . The adsorption energy as well as some structural parameters are presented in Table 2 . On the pristine α-Al2O3(0001) surface, the CO2 molecule weakly binds to one surface Al atom with a small adsorption energy of E ads = 0.36 eV (see Table 2), and CO2 still maintains a linear structure (not shown). While bent CO2 molecules were adsorbed on the surface with the deposition of Cun clusters at interfacial site between Cun cluster and Al2O3(0001) surface, resulting from synergistic catalysis associated with Cun-Al2O3 interface (Fig. 3). As the number of Cu atom in the cluster increases from n = 1 to 9, the calculated E ads are 1.00, 1.27, 1.20, 1.03, 1.43, 1.37, 1.33, 1.13 and 1.37 eV, respectively (Table 2). And corresponding CO bond lengths of adsorbed CO2 have been enlarged in varying degree (1.219 Å–1.281 Å). These divergence in E ads and CO bond lengths indicates that the degree of CO2 activation is sensitive to the size of Cun cluster anchored on α-Al2O3(0001) surface. To understand the effect of size and interface of the Cun/α-Al2O3 (0001) on CO2 activation, Bader charge of CO2 adsorption on the Cun/α-Al2O3(0001) is analysis as listed in Table 2. It can be seen that the net charge of CO2 molecule at the interface of Cun(n = 1–9)/α-Al2O3 (0001) is −0.47, −0.85, −0.86, −0.93, −1.14, −0.95, −0.93, −1.03 and −0.94 e, respectively. These results indicated the electron transfer from the Cun(n = 1–9)/α-Al2O3 (0001) substrate to the adsorbed CO2 molecule, leading to the negatively charged CO2. Furthermore, we investigated the possible descripts for determining the activation degree of CO2. From Fig. 4 a-b, we can clearly see that the deviation of CO bond lengths and ∠OC-O bond angles is closely related to the charge of CO2 moiety. The larger the deviation of CO bond length and ∠OC-O bond angle, the larger the magnitutes of charge of CO2 moiety, the better the CO2 activation. We also investigated the relationship between the average d -band center and charge of CO2 moiety. As shown in Fig. 4c, εd of Cun clusters exhibit linear relationships with the charge of CO2 moiety. The larger the εd, the larger charge of CO2 moiety, the better activate CO2 to promote hydrogenation. Hence, we can find that the deviation of CO bond lengths, OC-O bond angles from free CO2, and the average d-band center of Cun cluster can well descript for determining the activation degree of CO2. It is noted that, among the Cun(n = 1–9)/α-Al2O3 (0001), the largest value of E ads (1.43 eV) is obtained for the Cu5/α-Al2O3 surface (COa = 1.276 Å, COb = 1.324 Å, CCu = 1.938 Å, Oa-Cu = 2.050 Å, Ob-Al = 1.276 Å, ∠OC-O = 119.8⁰). And the activated CO2 on the Cu5/α-Al2O3 surface possess the longest bond length of CO bond (1.276 Å, 1.324 Å) and smallest bond angle of ∠OC-O (119.8⁰), which can be seen as CO2 − anion. All mentioned above indicates that the adsorbed CO2 on the Cu5/α-Al2O3 (0001) is more stable and is beneficial for the subsequent hydrogenation step (Fig. 3e, Tables 2, S2). The results were consistent with above analysis of the Cu5/α-Al2O3 (0001) (Table 1, Fig. 2a). To understand the nature of the activation for CO2 adsorption on the Cu5/Al2O3, electronic properties analysis, including the projected densities of states (pDOS), Bader charge and charge density difference (CDD) were further performed. DOS of CO2 molecule in gas phase, Cu-3d orbital, Al-3p orbital before and after CO2 adsorption on Cu5/Al2O3 were presented in Fig. 2c. As shown in Fig. 2c, there are Cu-3d and Al-3p orbital occurring near the Fermi level for Cu5/Al2O3. After being adsorption of CO2, the Cu-3d orbital of the supported Cu5 cluster was overlapped with the CO2 molecule. The Cu-3d orbital became delocalization, and then shifted to higher energy level. And 2πu orbital of CO2 shifted to lower energy level from near 8.0 eV to around 2.5 eV, indicating formation of d-πu interaction. Besides, partial delocalization of Al-3p orbital components and somewhat overlapped with CO2 orbital are also been observed. Overall, such synergistic interactions among the CO2 and the Cu5/Al2O3 effectively activated the CO2, which have a deep impact on further hydrogenation process. Further analysis of Bader charge shows that, among them all the Cun(n = 1–9)/α-Al2O3 (0001), adsorbed CO2 obtained the most electron from Cu5/Al2O3 (0001) (−1.14 e), result in the best CO2 activation on the Cu5/Al2O3 (0001) to CO2 δ− species (Table 2). Particularly, the obtained electrons of CO2 are significantly more than the lost electrons of supported Cu cluster, suggested that CO2 molecule was not only obtained electron from Cu cluster but also some transfer from Al2O3 due to the synergistic effect between Cu cluster and Al2O3. Additionally, the C atom in CO2 bonded with Cu atom obtained more electrons than that of O atoms in CO2, indicated that H atom will perfect to migrate to the activated C atom in CO2 for the information of HCOO*. Further charge density difference (CDD) of CO2/Cu5/Al2O3 (Fig. 2b) demonstrated that the obtained electrons of CO2 transfer from surface Al atom and Cu atoms of Cu5 cluster simultaneously, especially C atom obtained more electron. This was consistent with above Bader charge analysis (Table 2). CO2 synthesis to methanol on the interfacial site of the Cu5/α-Al2O3 (0001) The above-mentioned analysis presented that the synergistic catalytic between the Cu5 cluster and α-Al2O3 plays an important role for the enhanced activity of CO2. Next studies mainly focus on the reaction pathways of CO2 synthesis to methanol on the interfacial site of the Cu5/α-Al2O3 (0001). The potential reaction network for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol at the Cu5/α-Al2O3 (0001) interface is summarized in Fig. 5 . This network includes the formate route, the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) route and the direct CO bond cleavage route. Formate route firstly form HCOO* intermediate, then through a series of hydrogenation processes to form CH3OH. The RWGS route is initialized by formation of COOH*, next through RWGS process to generate CO*, then undergoes hydrogenation to CH3OH. While for the direct CO bond cleavage route, CO* intermediate is generated through the direct cleavage of CO bond of CO2, then further hydrogenation to produce CH3OH. All the reaction energies and activation barriers of the elementary reaction steps for these three pathways are summarized in Table 3 . Corresponding structures of intermediates and transition states are given in Fig. S2. Formate pathway The formate pathway of CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH on Cu5/α-Al2O3 (0001) is shown in Fig. 6 , and corresponding structures are displayed in Fig. S2. The reaction starts with the adsorption of CO2 and H2 on the interfacial sites of the Cu5/α-Al2O3 (0001) surface. The dissociative adsorption energy of adsorbed H2 is −1.18 eV, indicated that Cu5/α-Al2O3 (0001) surface can easily activate H2 to form H adatoms (Fig. S3). Then the C atom of activated CO2* with bent structure is attacked by the dissociated H atom to form HCOO* though reaction R1 (CO2* + H* → HCOO* + *), which is in line with above analysis of electronic structure (Table 2, Fig. 2b). This process is thermodynamically easy to occur with the reaction energy (Er ) of −0.57 eV and a low activation energy (Ea ) of 0.76 eV. Continued hydrogenation of HCOO* to H2COO* requires to undergo a high activation energy of 1.28 eV, which is endothermic with Er of +0.49 eV. It can be observed that the formation of H2COO* lead to CO bond length of CO2 elongation from 1.264 to 1.452 Å, indicating the weakening of CO bond. Thus, the third H tends to attack O atom of H2COO*, results in weakened CO bond break, then generates H2CO* and OH* which just need to overcome a small activation energy. In this reaction step, two possible structures of adsorbed OH* are found. One structure is the adsorbed OH* bonds with Cu atom and Al atom at the Cu5/α-Al2O3 (0001) interface simultaneously (R3: H2COO* + H* → H2CO* + OH*(Cu-Al)). The other one is the adsorbed OH* group bonds with two Cu atoms on the copper cluster (R4: H2COO* + H* → H2CO* + OH*(Cu-Cu)). It must be mentioned that, although these two possible steps have almost the same activation barrier, the reaction energy of R3 is lower 0.66 eV than that in R4, indicating OH* at the Cu5/α-Al2O3 (0001) interface more energetically stable. Next reaction pathway branches into two different routes, which is labelled by black line and blue line in Fig. 6, respectively. For the case of OH*(Cu-Al) and H2CO* at the interface, H2CO* is preferentially hydrogenated to H3CO* which is bonded with surface Al atom (labelled as mono-H3CO*) with low Ea of 0.11 eV and Er of −0.96 eV, followed OH*(Cu-Al) hydrogenated to form H2O* with Ea of 0.70 eV (black line). While for OH*(Cu-cu) and H2CO* on the supported Cu5 cluster, OH*(Cu-cu) firstly hydrogenates to form H2O with Ea of 1.51 eV, implying kinetically difficult for OH*(Cu-cu) hydrogenation (R8). Next H2CO* hydrogenate to produce H3CO* (R9) followed by the desorption of formed H2O with an activation energy of 0.37 eV (blue line). Compared with above two branch paths, the route with OH*(Cu-Al) and H2CO* at the interface is more like to occur due to lower energy barrier and energetically more favorable. To convenient for the later hydrogenation process, mono-H3CO* rotates to adsorb with surface Al atom and Cu atom simultaneously at the interface (labelled as bi-H3CO*) without energy barrier. Afterward, final hydrogenation of bi-H3CO* to produced methanol (R7: H3CO* + H* → H3COH*+ *) overcome an Ea of 0.87 eV with a reaction energy of +0.72 eV. In summary, hydrogenation of HCOO* to produce H2COO* is the rate-limiting step with activation energy of 1.28 eV, which is much lower than that of Cu(111) surface (1.60 eV) and Cu29 nanoparticle (1.41 eV) [62], indicated that the Cu5/Al2O3 catalyst exhibit excellent catalytic activity with respect to the conventional metal bulk surface and supported large nanoparticle. The H2COO* species adsorbed at the Cu5/Al2O3 interface by formation of 2 Cu-O bonds and 1 Al-O bond has high stability, due to the synergistic catalysis associated with interfacial site between Cu cluster and α-Al2O3(0001) surface. This was consistent with previous work for CO2 conversion on Pt4/In2O3 model [18]. Additionally, to further identify the rate-controlling step, DRC analysis was performed for microkinetic simulation with feed gasses mixture of CO2 and H2 in a 1:3 ratio under 1 atm pressure in 400−650 K as displayed in Fig. 9a. The hydrogenation of HCOO* is the rate-controlling step at the temperature over 550 K. While the generation of H3CO* becomes the key step to affect the rate of methanol synthesis at the temperature ranging from 500 to 540 K. At lower temperature (T< 490 K) the process of CH3OH* desorption become the rate-controlling step. RWGS + CO-hydrogenation pathway The RWGS+CO-hydrogenation pathway for methanol synthesis is also investigated (Figs. 7 , S3). The H atom firstly attack the O atom of activated CO2* into COOH* (R10) with higher energy barrier of 1.21 eV than that of formed *HCOO in formate pathway (0.76 eV). Then corresponding bond length of CO bond elongated from 1.292 Å to 1.374 Å, indicating weakening of the CO bond of CO2*. Then the weakening CO bond is broken, dissociated to CO* and H2O(g), with Ea of 1.95 eV and endothermic Er of +1.02 eV. Results reveal that it is difficult for the dissociation processes both in kinetics and thermodynamics views. Subsequently, dissociated CO* is hydrogenated to HCO* with a low Ea of 0.51 eV (R12). HCO* continuously hydrogenated to form H2CO* (R13: HCO* + H* → H2CO* + *, Er = −0.17 eV, Ea = 0.31 eV). Notably, now the structure of H2CO* intermediate was found the same as that in formate pathway. Hence, the following steps are all consistent with those in formate pathway (Fig. 6). The reaction intermediates for the whole catalytic process is in sequence of COOH*, CO*, HCO*, H2CO* and H3CO*, with binding energies of −3.84, −2.48, −3.93, −3.12 and −3.05/−4.20 eV, respectively. In summary, for the RWGS + CO-hydrogenation pathway the rate-limiting step is the hydrogenation of COOH* to CO*, which is endothermic and need to overcome much high energy barrier (1.95 eV), indicating the RWGS + CO-hydrogenation pathway is unlikely to happen. Further results of DRC analysis (Fig. 9b) shows that the desorption of CH3OH* is the rate-determining step at lower temperature (T< 450 K). When the temperature is above 470 K, the hydrogenation of COOH* to form CO* and H2O becomes the absolutely dominant step to affect the rate of methanol synthesis. Direct CO bond cleavage pathway In addition, direct CO bond cleavage pathway is also studied as shown in Figs. 8 and S3. In comparison, CO2* is more prone to cleave COb bond, which not only has a lower energy barrier of 0.81 eV than that of COa bond cleavage (2.43 eV), but also thermodynamically more likely to occur, probably due to the larger COb bond length (1.324 Å) than that of COa bond (1.276 Å). Then, the dissociated Ob* is hydrogenated to form OH* with low energy barrier of 0.76 eV and reaction energy of −1.01 eV. Followed hydrogenated of COa* to HCOa* has a low Ea of 0.64 eV (R16). In comparison, sequentially hydrogenation of HCOa* is more prone to form H2CO* which has lower energy barrier of 0.36 eV than that of formed HCOH* (1.52 eV). Subsequently, H2CO* is hydrogenated to form H3CO* which interact with Al2O3 by one Oa-Al bond (labelled as mono-H3CO*) (R18, Ea = 0.15 eV). To convenient for later hydrogenation process, mono-H3CO* rotates to bond with one surface Al atom and one Cu atom at the interface simultaneously (labelled as bi-H3CO*) without an energy barrier. Bi-H3CO* species is continuously hydrogenated to form methanol, and the adsorbed OH* species is hydrogenated to H2O* with an energy barrier of 1.10 eV (T23). Finally, formed H2O* and H3COH* is desorbed to the product CH3OH. In summary, for the direct CO bond cleavage pathway, the hydrogenation of OH* to form H2O* is the rate-limiting step with activation energy of 1.10 eV. The intermediates of whole catalytic process accord to the order of CO*, HCO*, H2CO*, H3CO* and H3COH*. Further DRC analysis displayed in Fig. 9 c show that the cleavage of CO2* is the rate-determining step at lower temperature, while the hydrogenation of OH* to produce H2O* control the rate of methanol synthesis at higher temperature. According to all of mentioned-above analysis, it can be concluded that the formate pathway and the direct CO bond cleavage pathway are competitive. While the RWGS + CO-hydrogenation pathway is impossible due to the high activation barrier. For the formate pathway, the hydrogenation of HCOO* to form H2COO* is the rate-limiting step with the Ea of 1.28 eV. The reactive intermediates for CO2 conversion to CH3OH accord to the order of HCOO*, H2COO*, H2CO* and H3CO*. Further DRC confirmed this step is the rate-dominant step when temperature is above 550 K. While for the direct CO bond cleavage pathway, reactive intermediates are in sequence of CO*, HCO*, H2CO* and H3CO*. The process of hydrogenation of OH* to H2O* has the highest activation barrier. Further DRC analysis suggests that this process is the rate-limiting step for CO2 synthesis at higher temperature. Conclusion Efficient converting CO2 into methanol has triggered enormous research due to mitigation of greenhouse effect and reducing of fossil fuels. While exploring highly active catalysts with efficient transformation of CO2 into methanol is a major challenge due to the difficulties with the chemical inertness of CO2. Single-atom catalysts (SAC) and single-cluster catalysts (SCC) in heterogeneous catalysts have attracted increasing attention due to its unique physical and chemical properties, and excellent catalytic performance. However, determined the active site of catalyst and understanding the promotional of different size effect are controversial, and reaction mechanism in the catalytic process is still unclear. In the present work, density functional theory calculations have been performed to study the size effects of sub-nanometer copper clusters anchored on α-Al2O3 (0001) system for CO2 activation and reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Our results show that CO2 was activated at interfaces between Cun(n = 1–9) cluster and α-Al2O3(0001) surface in a bent configuration, indicating synergistic catalysis associated with Cun -Al2O3 interfacial site. The introducing of Cun clusters anchored on α-Al2O3 (0001) surface can greatly improve the thermodynamic stability of CO2 chemisorption. Analysis of Bader charge show that there are charge transfer occurring from Cun/Al2O3 (0001) to CO2, leading to the negatively charged CO2 δ− moiety. The deviation of CO bonds length, ∠OC-O angle from free CO2, and average d -band center of supported Cu cluster could be excellent descripts for determining the activation degree of CO2. Especially, among all size of Cun cluster, Cu5/α-Al2O3(0001) system exhibit significantly higher activity for CO2 hydrogenation. The formats route, the CO bond cleavage route and the reverse water gas shift (RWGS)+CO-hydrogenation route of CO2 conversion at Cu5-Al2O3 interface was further examined. It is confirmed that the formate and the direct CO bond cleavage route are competitive, in which hydrogenation of HCOO* and HO* at the Cu5-Al2O3 interface is the rate-dominant step with an Ea of 1.28 eV and 1.10 eV, respectively. While the RWGS + CO-hydrogenation route is not feasible because of the high Ea of the hydrogenation of CO intermediate (1.95 eV). Therefore, controlling size and dispersion of copper cluster with optimized metal/oxide interface has great potential in designing excellent Cu-based catalysts for CO2 conversion to methanol. However, more works are also required to investigate the effects of larger size of supported Cun cluster (n ≥ 10) for the CO2 conversion. coredata.dc:description: The size-selected copper single-cluster catalysts(SCCs) play a crucial role in catalyzing of CO2 hydrogenation. However, nature of size effect and hydrogenation mechanism is still unclear. Here, Density functional theory(DFT) calculations were performed to investigate activation and reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over copper single-clusters catalyst anchored on α-Al2O3(0001). Our results show that Cun(n = 1–9)/Al2O3 catalysts significantly promote activation of CO2 in a bent configuration due to the synergistic interaction associated with Cun-Al2O3(0001) interfacial site. Bader charge analysis suggested electron transfer occurring from Cun-Al2O3(0001) interface to CO2, leading to negatively charged CO2. We find descriptors of deviation of CO2 bonds length and bonds angle, d -band center of Cun(n = 1–9) cluster that can well descript for determining activation degree of CO2. Especially, the Cu5/α-Al2O3(0001) has the best activity for CO2 hydrogenation among them. Furthermore, reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation at Cu5/Al2O3 interface have been explored. Methanol synthesis takes formate route and direct CO bond cleavage route competitive with rate-dominant step of HCOO* and HO* hydrogenation, respectively. While CO-hydrogenation produced by RWGS route is not feasible because of high activation barrier of formed CO intermediate(1.95 eV). This study will provide insight into designing and application of ultrahigh-performance Cu-based single-cluster catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation.
